section.title: run a program as another user
about sudo
section.para: The sudo program allows a user to start a program with the credentials of another user. Before this works, the system administrator has to set up the /etc/sudoers/etc/sudoers file. This can be useful to delegate administrative tasks to another user (without giving the root password).

The screenshot below shows the usage of sudosudo. User paul received the right to run useradd with the credentials of rootroot. This allows paul to create new users on the system without becoming root and without knowing the root password.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ useradd -m inge useradd: unable to lock password file paul@laika:~$ sudo useradd -m inge [sudo] password for paul: paul@laika:~$

section.title: setuid on sudo
section.para: The sudo binary has the setuidsetuid bit set, so any user can run it with the effective userid of root.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ ls -l `which sudo` -rwsr-xr-x 2 root root 107872 2008-05-15 02:41 /usr/bin/sudo paul@laika:~$

section.title: visudo
section.para: Check the man page of visudovisudo(1) before playing with the /etc/sudoers file.

section.title: sudo su
section.para: On some linux systems like Ubuntu and Kubuntu, the root user does not have a password set. This means that it is not possible to login as root (extra security). To perform tasks as root, the first user is given all sudo rightssudo(1) via the /etc/sudoers/etc/sudoers. In fact all users that are members of the admin group can use sudo to run all commands as root.
section.screen: root@laika:~# grep admin /etc/sudoers # Members of the admin group may gain root privileges %admin ALL=(ALL) ALL
section.para: The end result of this is that the user can type sudo su -sudo su - and become root without having to enter the root password. The sudo command does require you to enter your own password. Thus the password prompt in the screenshot below is for sudo, not for su.
